Over-the-Air Computation Empowered Federated Learning: A Joint Uplink-Downlink Design

Deyou Zhang, Ming Xiao, and Mikael Skoglund Division of Information Science and Engineering, KTH Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden
email: {deyou, mingx, skoglund}@kth.se
Abstract

In this paper, we investigate the communication designs of over-the-air computation (AirComp) empowered federated learning (FL) systems considering uplink model aggregation and downlink model dissemination jointly. We first derive an upper bound on the expected difference between the training loss and the optimal loss, which reveals that optimizing the FL performance is equivalent to minimizing the distortion in the received global gradient vector at each edge node. As such, we jointly optimize each edge node transmit and receive equalization coefficients along with the edge server forwarding matrix to minimize the maximum gradient distortion across all edge nodes. We further utilize the MNIST dataset to evaluate the performance of the considered FL system in the context of the handwritten digit recognition task. Experiment results show that deploying multiple antennas at the edge server significantly reduces the distortion in the received global gradient vector, leading to a notable improvement in recognition accuracy compared to the single antenna case.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, over-the-air computation, joint uplink-downlink design.

I Introduction

With the widespread deployment of 5G communication networks, there has been growing interest in exploring 6G communications in both academia and industry [1, 2, 3]. It is widely anticipated that 6G communications will rely on ubiquitous artificial intelligence to achieve data-driven machine learning (ML) solutions in large-dimensional and heterogeneous networks [3]. However, traditional ML techniques typically require a centralized data collection process, which consumes substantial communication and computation resources and often leads to severe latency. Additionally, such a centralized data collection process can also raise privacy and security concerns, particularly when dealing with sensitive data.

As an emerging distributed ML approach, federated learning (FL) provides a new paradigm to cope with these concerns [4]. In typical FL frameworks, it is unnecessary for smart edge nodes to reveal their local data to the edge server. Instead, FL repeatedly executes the following two processes. 1) Model aggregation: edge nodes upload their respective local model parameters111Local model parameters of each edge node are computed based on its received global model parameters and its own dataset, as detailed in Section II-A. Moreover, the computation of local model parameters is often referred to as local training. to the edge server, which averages over those parameters to obtain global model parameters. 2) Model dissemination: the edge server broadcasts global model parameters to edge nodes for the next local training. Since only model parameters instead of raw data are sent to the edge server, FL is capable of achieving privacy protection and relieving communication burdens.

Despite the advantages of FL, uploading local model parameters via traditional orthogonal multiple access (OMA) protocols is resource-demanding, and it has become a bottleneck for implementing FL in practice. In light of this, several recent works proposed to optimize resource allocation among edge nodes to enhance the communication efficiency in model uploading [5, 6]. Though with merits, those works did not exploit the waveform-superposition property of multiple-access channels and thus did not fully unleash the benefits of wireless communications. As an alternative, over-the-air computation (AirComp) empowered model aggregation has recently emerged [7, 8, 9].

The first AirComp-empowered model aggregation research appeared in [7], demonstrating that AirComp could significantly reduce the model uploading latency compared to its OMA counterpart. Meanwhile, gradient sparsification and compression methods were investigated in [8] to further alleviate the uplink communication burden. As preliminary works, only single-input single-output (SISO) configuration was considered in those literatures [7, 8]. To leverage the benefit of multi-antenna technology, authors in [9] focused on the single-input multiple-output (SIMO) configuration and proposed to jointly optimize edge node selection and the edge server receive beamforming vector to control the communication errors in model aggregation. While in [10], both multiple-input single-output (MISO) and multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) configurations were considered. Moreover, to better adapt to the wireless fading channel, authors in [10] introduced local learning rates and, based on which, proposed a modified federated averaging algorithm. Nonetheless, the beamforming designs in [9, 10] only considered the model aggregation phase and ignored the model dissemination phase. In realistic FL systems, the two phases are intertwined, and the quality of model transmission in one phase affects the other one. Consequently, the two phases need to be considered jointly such that new beamforming designs remain to be explored [11].

In this paper, we focus on a typical wireless FL system consisting of one multi-antenna edge server and multiple single-antenna edge nodes. AirComp is employed for model aggregation, and the popular uniform-forcing design [15] is adopted to recover a noisy version of the global gradient vector at each edge node after model dissemination. Different from existing works, we investigate the communication designs of AirComp-empowered FL considering uplink model aggregation and downlink model dissemination jointly.

Specifically, we first derive an upper bound on the expected difference between the training loss and the optimal loss, which reveals that optimizing the FL performance is equivalent to minimizing the mean squared error (MSE) between the target global gradient vector and the received one at each edge node. Then, we seek to jointly optimize each edge node transmit and receive equalization coefficients along with the edge server forwarding matrix to minimize the maximum MSE across all edge nodes, which is a highly non-convex optimization problem. Considering the uniform-forcing design criterion, we prove that the edge server forwarding matrix must be a rank-one matrix. Leveraging this property, we decompose the original problem into two subproblems and optimize the uplink and downlink transceiver designs separately. While each subproblem remains non-convex, we employ the matrix lifting technique to transform them into difference-of-convex (DC) programs, which can be efficiently solved using the successive convex approximation (SCA) technique. Furthermore, we utilize the MNIST dataset to evaluate the performance of the considered FL system in the context of the handwritten digit recognition task. Experiment results show that deploying multiple antennas at the edge server significantly reduces the MSE at each edge node and improves the recognition accuracy compared to the single antenna case.

Indeed, the literature on joint uplink-downlink communication design for FL was scarce [12, 13, 14]. Specifically, authors in [12] investigated the impact of different model quantization methods on FL learning performance considering both uplink and downlink transmission. In [13], FL over a multi-cell network accounting for inter-cell interference in both uplink and downlink communication was explored. However, both of these works only considered the SISO configuration. The closest work to ours is [14], where a multi-antenna edge server was also assumed. In this work, both uplink and downlink beamforming designs were considered but with different approaches.

We use |𝒟|𝒟|\mathcal{D}| to denote the cardinality of set 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}; ⟨𝐀,𝐁⟩𝐀𝐁\langle\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}\rangle to denote the inner product of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} and 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}. II System Model

In this section, we first provide some preliminary knowledge about FL and then introduce the AirComp-empowered FL framework. Note that both uplink model aggregation and downlink model dissemination are considered for communication designs.

II-A FL Systems

As depicted in Fig. 1, a typical FL system consists of an edge server and K𝐾K edge nodes. Edge node k𝑘k, ∀k∈𝒦≜{1,⋯,K}for-all𝑘𝒦≜1⋯𝐾\forall k\in{\cal K}\triangleq\{1,\cdots,K\}, has a local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\cal D}_{k} that contains Dk≜|𝒟k|≜subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘D_{k}\triangleq|{\cal D}_{k}| labeled data samples, denoted by {𝝃k,1,ζk,1}subscript𝝃𝑘1subscript𝜁𝑘1\{\bm{\xi}_{k,1},\zeta_{k,1}\}, ⋯,{𝝃k,Dk,ζk,Dk}⋯subscript𝝃𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝜁𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘\cdots,\{\bm{\xi}_{k,D_{k}},\zeta_{k,D_{k}}\}. Here, tuple {𝝃k,i,ζk,i}subscript𝝃𝑘𝑖subscript𝜁𝑘𝑖\{\bm{\xi}_{k,i},\zeta_{k,i}\} denotes the i𝑖i-th data sample in 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\cal D}_{k}, consisting of a feature vector 𝝃k,isubscript𝝃𝑘𝑖\bm{\xi}_{k,i} and its corresponding ground-truth label ζk,isubscript𝜁𝑘𝑖\zeta_{k,i}, ∀i∈{1,⋯,Dk}for-all𝑖1⋯subscript𝐷𝑘\forall i\in\{1,\cdots,D_{k}\}. The objective of FL is to seek a model parameter vector 𝜽∈ℛd𝜽superscriptℛ𝑑\bm{\theta}\in{\cal R}^{d} that minimizes the following global loss function

in a distributed manner, where f​(𝜽;𝝃k,i,ζk,i)𝑓𝜽subscript𝝃𝑘𝑖subscript𝜁𝑘𝑖f(\bm{\theta};\bm{\xi}_{k,i},\zeta_{k,i}) is termed sample-wise loss function quantifying the misfit of 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta} on the data sample {𝝃k,i,ζk,i}subscript𝝃𝑘𝑖subscript𝜁𝑘𝑖\{\bm{\xi}_{k,i},\zeta_{k,i}\}.

To this end, we follow [4, 5, 6, 7] and define the local loss function of 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta} on 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\cal D}_{k}, ∀k∈𝒦for-all𝑘𝒦\forall k\in{\cal K}, as

Then, the global loss function in (1) can be rewritten as

F​(𝜽)=1∑j=1KDj​∑k=1KDk​Fk​(𝜽).𝐹𝜽1superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾subscript𝐷𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝐹𝑘𝜽F(\bm{\theta})=\frac{1}{\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{K}D_{j}}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}D_{k}F_{k}(\bm{\theta}). (3)

In FL systems, the model parameter vector 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta} is trained in a distributed and iterative manner, where the l𝑙l-th training round consists of the following steps.

Local gradient computation: Denote 𝜽k[l−1]superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘delimited-[]𝑙1\bm{\theta}_{k}^{[l-1]} the local model parameter vector of edge node k𝑘k at the beginning of the l𝑙l-th training round. To update 𝜽k[l−1]superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘delimited-[]𝑙1\bm{\theta}_{k}^{[l-1]}, edge node k𝑘k leverages its dataset to compute a local gradient vector, given by

𝐠k[l]≜∇Fk​(𝜽k[l−1])=1D​∑i=1D∇f​(𝜽k[l−1];𝝃k,i,ζk,i).≜superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘delimited-[]𝑙∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘delimited-[]𝑙11𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐷∇𝑓superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘delimited-[]𝑙1subscript𝝃𝑘𝑖subscript𝜁𝑘𝑖{\mathbf{g}}_{k}^{[l]}~{}\triangleq~{}\nabla F_{k}(\bm{\theta}_{k}^{[l-1]})~{}=~{}\frac{1}{D}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{D}\nabla f(\bm{\theta}_{k}^{[l-1]};\bm{\xi}_{k,i},\zeta_{k,i}). (5)

Model aggregation: As shown in Fig. 1(a), the K𝐾K edge nodes upload their computed local gradient vectors to the edge server, which takes an average of these local gradient vectors to get the global gradient vector, i.e.,

𝐳[l]=1K​∑k=1K𝐠k[l].superscript𝐳delimited-[]𝑙1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘delimited-[]𝑙\mathbf{z}^{[l]}=\frac{1}{K}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}{\mathbf{g}}_{k}^{[l]}. (6)

Model dissemination: As shown in Fig. 1(b), the edge server disseminates 𝐳[l]superscript𝐳delimited-[]𝑙\mathbf{z}^{[l]} to the K𝐾K edge nodes for local model update.

𝜽k[l]=𝜽k[l−1]−η[l]​𝐳[l],superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘delimited-[]𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘delimited-[]𝑙1superscript𝜂delimited-[]𝑙superscript𝐳delimited-[]𝑙\bm{\theta}_{k}^{[l]}=\bm{\theta}_{k}^{[l-1]}-\eta^{[l]}{\mathbf{z}}^{[l]}, (7)

where η[l]superscript𝜂delimited-[]𝑙\eta^{[l]} is termed the learning rate.

Such a procedure is repeated for a fixed number of L𝐿L rounds or until a global consensus is achieved.

II-B AirComp-Empowered Model Aggregation

To reduce communication resource consumption, we adopt AirComp for model uploading. Specifically, at each training round, the K𝐾K edge nodes upload their respective local gradient vectors to the edge server using the same time-frequency resources. By properly controlling their transmit and receive equalization coefficients and the forwarding matrix of the edge server, a noisy version of the target global gradient vector can be constructed, as detailed below.

First of all, we compute the first-order and second-order statistics of each local gradient vector:

g¯k[l]superscriptsubscript¯𝑔𝑘delimited-[]𝑙\displaystyle\bar{g}_{k}^{[l]} =\displaystyle= 1d​∑i=1dgk,i[l],1𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑖delimited-[]𝑙\displaystyle\frac{1}{d}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{d}g_{k,i}^{[l]}, (8a)
δk[l]superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑘delimited-[]𝑙\displaystyle\delta_{k}^{[l]} =\displaystyle= 1d​∑i=1d(gk,i[l]−g¯k[l])2.1𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑔delimited-[]𝑙𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript¯𝑔𝑘delimited-[]𝑙2\displaystyle\sqrt{\frac{1}{d}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{d}\left(g^{[l]}_{k,i}-\bar{g}_{k}^{[l]}\right)^{2}}. (8b)

Through (9), gk,i[l]subscriptsuperscript𝑔delimited-[]𝑙𝑘𝑖g^{[l]}_{k,i} is normalized as a zero-mean unit-variance symbol sk,i[l]subscriptsuperscript𝑠delimited-[]𝑙𝑘𝑖s^{[l]}_{k,i}, ∀k∈𝒦for-all𝑘𝒦\forall k\in{\cal K}.

The received global gradient vector through wireless channels inevitably becomes inaccurate due to fading and noise, leading to a negative effect on the FL learning performance333In this paper, the two terms “learning performance” and “convergence performance” are somehow equivalent. Specifically, we define an FL system to have good learning performance when its training loss is close to the optimal loss after some iterations., as detailed in Section III.

III FL Convergence Performance in the Presence of Gradient Error

In this section, we analyze the convergence property of the considered wireless FL system, which motivates the proposed uplink and downlink transceiver designs in the next section. To proceed, we follow [5, 6, 16, 19] and make the following assumptions.

Assumption 1

The global loss function F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot) is uniformly Lipschitz continuous with parameter ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0, such that for any 𝛉,𝛉′∈ℛd𝛉superscript𝛉′superscriptℛ𝑑\bm{\theta},\bm{\theta}^{\prime}\in{\cal R}^{d}, we have

F​(𝜽′)≤F​(𝜽)+(𝜽′−𝜽)T​∇F​(𝜽)+ρ2​‖𝜽′−𝜽‖2.𝐹superscript𝜽′𝐹𝜽superscriptsuperscript𝜽′𝜽𝑇∇𝐹𝜽𝜌2superscriptnormsuperscript𝜽′𝜽2F(\bm{\theta}^{\prime})\leq F(\bm{\theta})+\left(\bm{\theta}^{\prime}-\bm{\theta}\right)^{T}\nabla F(\bm{\theta})+\frac{\rho}{2}\left\|\bm{\theta}^{\prime}-\bm{\theta}\right\|^{2}. (19)
Assumption 2

The global loss function F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot) is strongly convex with respect to parameter μ>0𝜇0\mu>0, such that for any 𝛉,𝛉′∈ℛd𝛉superscript𝛉′superscriptℛ𝑑\bm{\theta},\bm{\theta}^{\prime}\in{\cal R}^{d}, we have

F​(𝜽′)≥F​(𝜽)+(𝜽′−𝜽)T​∇F​(𝜽)+μ2​‖𝜽′−𝜽‖2.𝐹superscript𝜽′𝐹𝜽superscriptsuperscript𝜽′𝜽𝑇∇𝐹𝜽𝜇2superscriptnormsuperscript𝜽′𝜽2F(\bm{\theta}^{\prime})\geq F(\bm{\theta})+\left(\bm{\theta}^{\prime}-\bm{\theta}\right)^{T}\nabla F(\bm{\theta})+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{\theta}^{\prime}-\bm{\theta}\right\|^{2}. (20)

Suppose that the global loss function F​(𝜽)𝐹𝜽F\left(\bm{\theta}\right) indeed satisfies the above two assumptions and the learning rate η[l]superscript𝜂delimited-[]𝑙\eta^{[l]} is set to 1/ρ1𝜌{1}/{\rho}. Following [19], we can derive that

Proof:

Refer to Appendix A. ∎

Since λ∈(0,1)𝜆01\lambda\in(0,1), when L→∞→𝐿L\rightarrow\infty, λL→0→superscript𝜆𝐿0\lambda^{L}\rightarrow 0, and we can thus simplify (23) as

It can be observed from (24) that FL recursions over wireless channels still converge, though a gap between F​(𝜽⋆)𝐹superscript𝜽⋆F(\bm{\theta}^{\star}) and limL→∞𝔼​[F​(𝜽k[L+1])]subscript→𝐿𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘delimited-[]𝐿1\lim\nolimits_{L\to\infty}{\mathbb{E}}[F(\bm{\theta}_{k}^{[L+1]})] exists due to communication errors. In the next section, we will jointly optimize each edge node transmit and receive equalization coefficients along with the edge server forwarding matrix to minimize the maximum MSE among the K𝐾K edge nodes in each training round, aiming to improve the performance of the considered wireless FL system.

IV Joint Uplink-Downlink Design

To proceed, we focus on the l𝑙l-th training round and take the maximum MSE among the K𝐾K edge nodes as the objective function to construct the following optimization problem:

(𝒫0)​min𝐌,{ak},{bk}⁡max∀k∈𝒦⁡{|ak|2​(σs2​𝐪kH​𝐌𝐌H​𝐪k+σk2)}subscript𝒫0subscript𝐌subscript𝑎𝑘subscript𝑏𝑘subscriptfor-all𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠2superscriptsubscript𝐪𝑘𝐻superscript𝐌𝐌𝐻subscript𝐪𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2\displaystyle(\mathcal{P}_{0})\min\limits_{\mathbf{M},\{a_{k}\},\{b_{k}\}}\max\limits_{\forall k\in{\cal K}}\left\{\big{|}a_{k}\big{|}^{2}\left(\sigma_{s}^{2}\mathbf{q}_{k}^{H}\mathbf{M}\mathbf{M}^{H}\mathbf{q}_{k}+\sigma_{k}^{2}\right)\right\} (25a)

V Numerical Results

We consider a three-dimensional coordinate system, where the location of the edge server is set to (−50,0,10)50010\left(-50,0,10\right) meters, and the K=20𝐾20K=20 edge nodes are uniformly distributed in the region of ([0,20],[−10,10],0)02010100\left([0,20],[-10,10],0\right) meters. The uplink and downlink channels between edge node k𝑘k and the edge server, i.e., 𝐡ksubscript𝐡𝑘\mathbf{h}_{k}, and 𝐪kHsubscriptsuperscript𝐪𝐻𝑘\mathbf{q}^{H}_{k}, ∀k∈𝒦for-all𝑘𝒦\forall k\in{\cal K}, suffer from both path loss and small-scale fading [17]. The path loss model is expressed as PL​(Γ)=C0​(Γ/Γ0)−κPLΓsubscript𝐶0superscriptΓsubscriptΓ0𝜅\textsf{PL}(\Gamma)=C_{0}\left(\Gamma/\Gamma_{0}\right)^{-\kappa}, where C0=30subscript𝐶030C_{0}=30 dB accounts for the path loss at the reference distance of Γ0=1subscriptΓ01\Gamma_{0}=1 meter, ΓΓ\Gamma denotes the link distance, and κ=2.2𝜅2.2\kappa=2.2 is the path loss component. The small-scale fading is modeled as

χ1+χ+11+χ​𝒞​𝒩​(0,1),𝜒1𝜒11𝜒𝒞𝒩01\sqrt{\frac{\chi}{1+\chi}}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{1+\chi}}{\cal CN}(0,1),

where χ=1𝜒1\chi=1 is termed the Rician factor. Moreover, we set σs2=−50superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠250\sigma_{s}^{2}=-50 dBW, σk2=−50superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘250\sigma_{k}^{2}=-50 dBW, and Pk=0subscript𝑃𝑘0P_{k}=0 dBW, ∀k∈𝒦for-all𝑘𝒦\forall k\in{\cal K}.

Regarding the learning purpose, we use the MNIST dataset [20] to simulate the handwritten digit recognition task. Specifically, by using cross-entropy as the loss function, we train a fully connected neural network consisting of 784 inputs and 10 outputs, i.e., the number of model parameters d=7840𝑑7840d=7840. The training set of 60,000 samples is equally divided into 20 shards of size D=3000𝐷3000D=3000 in a non-IID manner, and each shard is assigned to one edge node as its local dataset. The test dataset has 10,000 different samples, and we adopt test accuracy, defined as # of correctly recognized handwritten-digits10000∈[0,1]# of correctly recognized handwritten-digits1000001\frac{\text{\# of correctly recognized handwritten-digits}}{10000}\in[0,1], to evaluate the FL learning performance. The total number of training rounds L=50𝐿50L=50, and the learning rate η[l]superscript𝜂delimited-[]𝑙\eta^{[l]} is set to 0.010.010.01, ∀l=1,⋯,Lfor-all𝑙1⋯𝐿\forall l=1,\cdots,L.

In Fig. 2(a), we plot the average MSE of the K𝐾K edge nodes, defined as 1K​d​∑k=1K𝔼​[‖𝐞k[l]‖2]1𝐾𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐞𝑘delimited-[]𝑙2\frac{1}{Kd}\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}{\mathbb{E}}\big{[}\|\mathbf{e}_{k}^{[l]}\|^{2}\big{]}, ∀l=1,⋯,Lfor-all𝑙1⋯𝐿\forall l=1,\cdots,L. From this figure, we immediately observe that the average MSE of the K𝐾K edge nodes drops significantly when we increase the number of antennas at the edge server, demonstrating the great potential of introducing multiple antennas at the edge server. Moreover, by increasing the forwarding power of the edge server from 101010 dBw to 202020 dBw, the average MSE also drops notably. We can also observe from Fig. 2(a) that the curve of the average MSE becomes smoother when the number of antennas at the edge server is increased, exhibiting the “channel hardening” effect. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 2(b), the recognition accuracy improves significantly by increasing the number of antennas at the edge server from N=1𝑁1N=1 to N=4𝑁4N=4 or by increasing Pssubscript𝑃𝑠P_{s} from 101010 dBw to 202020 dBw, which can be attributed to the decreasing MSE and thus corroborates Theorem 1.

VI Conclusions

In this paper, we focused on an AirComp-empowered FL system and studied its communication designs by considering uplink model aggregation and downlink model dissemination jointly, which was different from most existing works. We analyzed the convergence performance of the considered FL system, demonstrating that it was related to the MSE between the target global gradient vector and the received one at each edge node. Accordingly, we further optimized each edge node transmit and receive equalization coefficients along with the edge server forwarding matrix to minimize the maximum MSE across all edge nodes. The performance of the considered FL system was also evaluated through the handwritten digit recognition task. Experiment results verified that deploying multiple antennas at the edge server can significantly reduce the MSE at each edge node, leading to a remarkable improvement in the recognition accuracy compared to the single antenna case.
